Baltimore Society of the Archeological Institute of America. The

professors in American universities,
and for all graduate students who
are doing original research, is contained in the , offer made by the
Kahn Foundation for the Foreign
Travel of American Teachers. In
the hope of broadening the outlook
of the men who are entrusted with
shaping the minds of the American
youth, and of giving them some acquaintance with the world of men
and affairs and aiding them to free
themselves from narrow national
prejudices, Mr. Albert Kahn, of
Paris, offers annually two scholarships of three thousand dollars each
the awarding of which is in the
hands of a committee of American
trustees. The recipient of the scholarship is expected to spend a year
in foreign travel, visiting the various countries of Europe together
with Egypt, India, China, Japan,

Mr. Marbury's Letter.

Professor Buchner's interview on
"Hopkins' Publicity," published last
week, has called forth from Mr.
Ogle Marbury, president of the
Class of 1902, a letter which is
printed in another column of this
paper. Mr. Marbury does not question the energy of the authorities
toward giving the University publicity; he merely takes exception to
one or two of the methods which
Dr. Buchner has outlined. With
certain of his criticisms THE NEWSLETTER is inclined to agree—for
instance, his dissent from Dr. Buchner's statement that "The best advertisement of the Johns Hopkins
University is an alumnus on a college faculty." Dr. Buchner's statement is true in one sense, and in
another sense misleading. Such an
advertisement is the best that the
University can have in what it
shows, but it is rather inadequate

The tryout for positions on the

been chosen as the subject of the
interclass and intercollegiate debates: "Resolved, That Without Regard to the Obligations of the HayPaunceforte Treaty, the Tolls of the
Panama Canal Should be the Same
for the Merchant Vessels of all Nations." It is understood that the
term "all nations" includes the
United States of America. Those
who wish to compete for the position of adviser only will be required

subject given above. An unusual
number of contestants, most of
whom have had wide experience in
public speaking, have decided to
come out for the junior team.
Dr. French will hold the tryout
for positions on the senior team on
Friday the 31st, at one o'clock.
The Debating Council has announced that the presidents of the
junior and senior classes, both of
whom are members of the Debating
Council, will flip coins at the end
of this month to decide which side
of Panama question the junior and
senior teams, respectively, shall take
in the coming debate.
The Council has announced also
that the interclass debates will be
held on March 7, and the intercollegiate on April 9.
